justification: “To measure risky decision-making in the laboratory, we employed a computerized version of the cups task (Levin & Hart, 2003).”
“We used developmentally appropriate versions of the Domain Specific Risk-Taking Scale (DOSPERT) to measure the self-reported likelihood of participants engaging in ‘real-world’ risky behaviors.”
In the prospect theory model description the authors state: “λ represents loss aversion…” and model this parameter to quantify the construct.
The methods note that “ρ represents risk aversion” within the fitted prospect theory model, indicating this parameter operationalizes risk-aversion.
The prospect-theory section explains that “μ is known as a choice consistency parameter. Greater μ values indicate more consistency across decisions,” directly tying the construct to the μ estimate.

When describing the target model the authors write, “we interpret the threshold parameter τ as the amount of reward needed to justify the degree of risk,” showing τ operationalizes this threshold construct.

measured_by: Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence – Second Edition (WASI-II)
justification: Participant IQ was assessed with “age-adjust percentile scores on the WASI-II,” indicating the construct IQ was measured by the WASI-II.

measured_by: Cups Task risk-reward decomposition (expected value parameter)
justification: The risk-reward decomposition defined “reward (i.e., return) as the expected value (EV) associated with a risky decision,” using this EV term to index sensitivity to reward.

measured_by: Cups Task risk-reward decomposition (standard deviation parameter)
justification: In the same decomposition the authors defined “risk as the standard deviation (SD) of the outcome distribution for risky choices,” making the SD term the quantitative measure of risk sensitivity.
